Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Porous Tantalum Cementless and Cemented Tibial Components in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: We randomised 145 patients into two groups

Intervention.evidence: Group 1 received a porous tantalum cementless tibial component, and Group 2 received a cemented conventional tibial component

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial investigates whether a porous tantalum cementless tibial component offers superior clinical outcomes compared to a conventional cemented component in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were the Knee Society Score (KSS) and WOMAC Osteoarthritis Index, assessed preoperatively and at 15 days, 6 months, and 5 years postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: We randomised 145 patients into two groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 5-year follow-up, the mean KSS was 90.4 (range, 68–100; 95% CI, ±1.6) for Group 1 and 86.5 (range, 56–99; 95% CI, ±2.4) for Group 2, with an effect size of 3.88 ± 2.87.

Harms.evidence: No significant differences were found in the frequency of complications or aseptic loosening between the groups.
